titles.title: Akame ga Kill!
murder city
Убийца Акаме
Убийцата Акаме
AkaKill
アカメが斬る!
Akame ga Kill!
Akame ga Kill!
Red Eyes Sword - Akame ga Kill
Червенооката убийца
斩! 赤红之瞳

recommendations.recommendation: Visual and audio, blood and flying body parts are ok, but story...
starts slow, ends fast. most characters are faced with tragedy. overall, not a really bad watch

honestly it was really amazing but i don`t know about anyone else but i felt as tho the ending was rushed. it would have probably been a lot better if they would have done 2 seasons instead of just a 24 episodes
One of the best bloody-bloody-violence show with Good Soundtrack. Kinda out of track from the Manga, but you won`t care if u are not reading the manga. still a good watch after all~

For an anime that uses manga as plot material, I would say this is a good watch for many reasons.
_ Gore: love it!! _ Strong heroines: you have to feel bad for the heroes sometimes. _ The ending: some say it bad. I find it average for my taste. At least, it`s not a typical stupid shounen show which portraits stupid heroes suddenly get a power up and kill the villains. As long as they keep the message consistent, I don`t care how "off" the anime is.
Again, "It`s all about the taste".
great action/super power anime with OTT violence and just the right amount of humour...worth watching!

This was definitely an interesting watch. Gritty life of an assassin team trying to overthrow the corrupted government. Very interesting characters with good character development. The latter makes you care for both the protagonists and the villains (some of them). However this overly tragic almost predictable outcome is kind of off putting, for me at least. Definitely recommended
one of the best this season.
ONE of the best among violence this season
i really liked it.it nailed me to my seat and i just watched non stop.kinda violent and funny and of course sad..didn`t really like any recent animes but this one restored my hope.go watch it
The anime is good. Characters are interesting, fights are not boring and outcomes not very predictible.
Anime + Game of thrones = Akame ga Kill!
I woud say this is 1 of the best anime this year recommend watching this strongly
Awesome fight scenes, great art. Solid story & well developed characters. Gets you attached just in time to punch you in the feels over & over.

Not bad at all. It stays true to the manga until the end, but it ends nice. Gory, unpredictable with a touch of Game of thrones, sick and twisted but enjoyable. It was a nice watch and it was worth it.
This show has a lot of trump cards to keep it interesting
solid anime 8 out of 10. It is complete and it has a solid good realistic ending.

anime.description: Tatsumi is a self-acknowledge country bumpkin who is nonetheless a well trained fighter. He and two companions leave their remote village to head to the Imperial City to find a way to relieve their friends and family from ruinous taxation imposed by the authorities. Yet the Imperial City is filled with unimaginable amounts of corruption and evil from supernatural sources. Tatsumi is immediately swindled after reaching the City and nearly loses everything soon after, but finds himself allied with an unlikely group of assassins. Source: ANN

tag.name: maintenance tags
tag.description: These tags are used for maintenance.

tag.name: military
tag.description: The military, also known as the armed forces, are forces authorized and legally entitled to use deadly force so as to support the interests of the state and its citizens. The task of the military is usually defined as defence of the state and its citizens and the prosecution of war against foreign powers. The military may also have additional functions within a society, including construction, emergency services, social ceremonies, and guarding critical areas. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: moe
tag.description: Moe is a Japanese slang loanword that refers to feelings of strong affection mainly towards characters in anime, manga, and video games. Moe, however, has also gained usage to refer to feelings of affection towards any subject. Moe can be related to lust; however, pure lust without other feelings is considered outside its scope. The word Moe originated in the late 1980s and early 1990s in Japan and is of uncertain origin, although there are several theories on how it came into use. At the anime level, the http://anidb.net/t7146 [cute girls doing cute things (CGDCT)] tag may also apply. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: shounen
tag.description: In the context of manga and associated media, shounen, literally meaning "youth" and often also specifically "boy", refers to a male audience roughly between the ages of 10 and 18. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: robot
tag.description: A robot is an automatically guided machine, able to do tasks on its own. Another common characteristic is that by its appearance or movements, a robot often conveys a sense that it has intent or agency of its own. Not to be confused with android (human-like robot).

tag.name: dragon
tag.description: Very intelligent mythical beings - a cross between a very large lizard and a dinosaur - that breath fire, and have a knack for kidnapping damsels, thus distressing them. In Fantasy anime this perceptive species often lives secluded from human civilisation, protectors of long lost knowledge. Dragons seem to be on the verge of extinction.

tag.name: content indicators
tag.description: The content indicators branch is intended to be a less geographically specific tool than the `age rating` used by convention, for warning about things that might cause offence. Obviously there is still a degree of subjectivity involved, but hopefully it will prove useful for parents with delicate children, or children with delicate parents. Note: Refer to further guidance on http://wiki.anidb.net/w/Categories:Content_Indicators [the Wiki page] for how to apply tag weights for content indicators.

tag.name: dynamic
tag.description: Some of the central structural elements in anime are: Plot Continuity How does the plot or several plots unfold. Are they a strictly linear retelling of one big continuing story, a serial, possibly with several side stories, or is the content chopped into a set of unconnected episodes, only sharing the same setting and characters? Stereotype Characters Then there is the question of the character set presentation. Is it completely original, or is it your usual stereotypical character cast. Both choices have their merit, for example it would not really make much sense to reinvent the wheel for a harem anime. Fans of that genre come to expect their favourite stereotype protagonists. Plot Twists Finally there is the question of how complex the plot / the story unfolds. Are there side-plots that merge into the main plot leading to unexpected plot twists, or is the anime quite predictable? The latter would not be appropriate for detective stories. In harem anime on the other hand a foreseeable outcome is actually something the fans will come to expect.

tag.name: target audience
tag.description: Anime, like everything else in the modern world, is targeted towards specific audiences, both implicitly by the creators and overtly by the marketing. While categories are associated with specific sex and age groups, this is not a bar on the anime being enjoyed by people who don`t fit into that band; not only do crossover titles exist, but the categories also have a considerable following outside their main demographic, and a person might as well enjoy anime from all categories. Still, does not invalidate the usefulness of marking a title as one of the categories; the same themes will likely be treated differently in anime geared for different audiences. Only one should not jump the gun and assume that a title will be more or less serious or present content in this or that way due to its target audience, or conversely assume the target audience on the content and its presentation alone. As such, the audience categories help form a broad impression of how a title might work with the announced themes, but offer little to no in-depth information about specific content or its treatment. The audience categories originate from manga magazines, which group titles of a same intended audience into a magazine that is advertised as belonging to that category, and so manga-based anime will have the category from their parent work. As for anime based on other works, the audience is often debatable, but comparing information such as time slot to the manga-based anime generally helps figure out the most likely possibility. If the parent material was classified under multiple audiences over time (for example, it was originally shounen, but then as the plot changed and became more mature, it was reclassified as seinen), and the anime adapts parent material time periods covering multiple audiences, we tag all audiences covered by the anime adaptation.

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: fetishes
tag.description: Everything under fetishes (except for Bishounen and Juujin) is strictly only meant for hentai (18 Restricted) and ecchi anime. In case of ecchi, it must be the main element of the show and not when there`s only some of it, for example, there`s some ecchi in Shinseiki Evangelion, but the fact you get to see Asuka`s pantsu doesn`t warrant it the schoolgirl fetish category. So be careful to which ecchi show you add fetishes; it`s fairly straightforward with hentai, though. Overall, this category tree is to satisfy the needs of people with different fetishes, so they can search for what tingles their tangle; hence why this is restricted to hentai and full ecchi shows.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: setting
tag.description: The setting describes in what time and place an anime takes place. To a certain extent it describes what you can expect from the world in the anime.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: place
tag.description: The places the anime can take place in. Includes more specific places such as a country on Earth, as well as more general places such as a dystopia or a mirror world.

tag.name: calling your attacks
tag.description: "GIGAAAAAA DRIIIIIILLL BREAKEEEEEERRR" If you can do something more impressive than just throw a punch, your attack(s) must have an equally impressive name. More than that, you have to call it out as you launch the attack. It doesn`t matter if it`s a martial arts move, a magical spell or your secret superweapon, if you can`t say its name, it just isn`t nearly as cool or effective. Having a special attack is always a must, but not impressive enough. Every special attack needs a name. A really awesome and outstanding name which is easy to remember and even easier and impressive to yell. Because it just is not enough to name your attack. No, to unleash the full power of your attack, you have to call its name in your most MANLY and LOUDEST voice. It does not matter whether it is a martial arts move, a magical spell or flying drills from your mecha, if you can`t call its name, it just isn`t nearly as cool or effective. Not a requirement but wearing shades while calling your attack makes it at least twice as cool, moreover giving your mecha or magical companion shades too results in an immeasurable level of awesomeness, bringing down every enemy just through the POWER OF YOUR VOICE. A standard feature of practically every mecha, mahou shoujo, high fantasy, or martial arts anime. [Source: TV Tropes]

tag.name: collateral damage
tag.description: The usually action orientated anime does not only show large amounts of combat and weapon use, but also the incidental massive destruction of property, often due to the inability of the protagonists to aim properly. Example: Mecha duking it out in a densely populated urban area.

tag.name: gunfights
tag.description: Fights where two or more parties are firing guns at one another.

tag.name: bullet time
tag.description: Bullet time refers to a simulation of variable speed (i.e. slow motion, time-lapse, …) and is characterized both by its extreme transformation of time and space to show normally imperceptible and un-filmable events, such as flying bullets. Most infamous scene using this technique, Neo dodging bullets in The Matrix film.

tag.name: swordplay
tag.description: The act or art of using a sword or similar weapon skillfully.

tag.name: super power
tag.description: Be it an ancient Greek Heracles, a cybernetic muscle-man, or a fourteen year-old girl in a mini-skirted sailor suit. As long as they have super powers, they`re in the show.

tag.name: fictional location
tag.description: A fictional location is a place or world which is run by different set of rules than our common and ordinary world. This may include completely fictional worlds with no semblance of Earth, computer-generated worlds, fantasy worlds, magical worlds, parallel worlds accessible through portals, and so on. Or it may be fictional places like floating islands, dungeons or planets, which can co-exist with ordinary Earth, but are otherwise separate from it. A world that generally shares the characteristics of, and/or is generally indistinguishable from the real world (bar research on a "more than cursory" level), would NOT be considered a fictional world. A good example is http://anidb.net/a4521 [Code Geass]. It contains several real world nationalities, such as http://anidb.net/a4521 [China], http://anidb.net/t2672 [Japan] (now Area 11), http://anidb.net/t5091 [India], etc, along with fictional nationalities such as http://anidb.net/t2361 [Britannia]. China, Japan, and India are easily identified with a cursory look. The location is unmistakably the planet Earth, even though national borders have been redrawn. The fictional world should only be tagged if it plays a materially important role in the plot and setting; generally, an episodic occurrence of a fictional world should not be tagged. A fantasy world is a type of fictional world, part of a fictional universe. Typical worlds involve, but are not limited to: magic or magical abilities, and/or a medieval theme. Some examples include: a parallel world tenuously connected to Earth via magical portals or items; a fictional Earth-like planet in the remote past or future; or an entirely independent world set in another universe. Many fantasy worlds draw heavily on real world history, geography, and sociology, and also on folklore.

tag.name: human enhancement
tag.description: Human enhancement can take various forms: It can be something comparatively non-intrusive as a power-up drug, a form of machine implantation or cyberization (http://anidb.net/a4414 [SAC Solid State Society]), or outright - possibly atrocious - genetic manipulation (http://anidb.net/a361 [Ao no 6 Gou]). Plot-wise enhanced protagonists in anime usually have to pay a price for their enhancements, be it physical or mental.

tag.name: mecha
tag.description: Mecha in Japanese basically means mechanical things; everything from an electric whisk or a car to a spaceship or a robot. Here however we limit it to the more exotic things usually referred to as mecha anime: robots, whether controlled by a human or not, and their ilk. See Androids, Piloted Robots, Power Suits, Robot Helpers, Transforming Robots for a more specific classification.

tag.name: piloted robot
tag.description: Piloted Robots are, as the name suggests, robots that cannot control themselves; they need to be steered from somewhere, this can be from a human sitting inside or a remote controlled option.

tag.name: large breasts
tag.description: Large breasts are breasts a fair notch larger than average, as found in some adolescent girls or fully grown women; however, as anime has no upper limit to breast size, the definition applies somewhat differently. To be considered large, breasts in anime must be bigger than real-life natural ones or natural-seeming fake ones, to the point they`d appear weirdly or even abnormally large in real-life females. On the high end of the spectrum, breasts that are as big as the character`s head or possibly a bit bigger are still considered large; however, breasts that take at least as much space as the rest of the chest or the abdomen, or that are almost as big but have an absurdly unnatural shape, are the less common http://anidb.net/t1774 [gigantic breasts] instead.

tag.name: violence
tag.description: Violence is the use of physical force against oneself or another entity, compelling action against one`s will on pain of being hurt. Note: Refer to further guidance on http://wiki.anidb.net/w/Categories:Content_Indicators [the Wiki page] for how to apply tag weights for content indicators.

tag.name: plot continuity
tag.description: Consistency of the characteristics of persons, plot, objects, places and events seen by the viewer. A single linear focused plot is highly continuous. A truly random plot is highly discontinuous.

tag.name: manga
tag.description: Manga is the lifeblood that drives the anime industry. Everything and its mother is based on manga. However! There are exceptions where the manga was not the basis for the anime. It`s common practice to make manga adaptations of many popular anime, there`s a manga based on Evangelion, and two (one shounen and one shoujo) based on each of Escaflowne and Mahou Tsukai Tai. Also it`s quite common to release manga and anime versions of a story in parallel, for instance Nadesico and Shoujo Kakumei Utena. There are also cases where an anime continues in a manga, as in the case of Angel Beats! and Angel Beats: Heaven`s Door, or reverse. See also http://anidb.net/t6493 [manhua] and http://anidb.net/t5010 [manhwa].

tag.name: skimpy clothing
tag.description: When a job needs to get done you need the appropriate clothing on the appropriate persons. That calls for preferably scantily clad young ladies. Spies will dress in sexy outfits, even when the mission explicitly calls for them to not to be noticed. Female warriors will charge into battle wearing armour that does not protect the vital organs. Bridge officers on a military starship will be issued go-go boots with their uniforms. Examples are the women in VanDread, AIKa or the most famous incarnation of that tag, the Strike Witches and their precursor the Sky Girls.

tag.name: action
tag.description: Action anime usually involve a fairly straightforward story of good guys versus bad guys, where most disputes are resolved by using physical force. It often contains a lot of shooting, explosions and fighting.

tag.name: angst
tag.description: A feeling of general discomfort and uneasiness is present due to either trivial or more serious reasons, often accompanied by depression. Warning: may contain copious amounts of brooding and sighing. Etymology: "Angst" is a German word meaning fear or anxiety.

tag.name: science fiction
tag.description: Science fiction stories usually focus on how situations could be different in the future when we are more technologically advanced; due to either our own achievements or having met with other civilizations whom we have learned from.

tag.name: fantasy
tag.description: Fantasy is a genre of fiction that uses magic and other supernatural phenomena as a primary element of plot, theme, or setting. Many works within the genre take place in fictional worlds where magic is common. Fantasy is generally distinguished from science fiction and horror by the expectation that it steers clear of (pseudo-)scientific and macabre themes, respectively, though there is a great deal of overlap between the three (which are subgenres of speculative fiction). In popular culture, the genre of fantasy is dominated by its medievalist form, especially since the worldwide success of The Lord of the Rings books by J. R. R. Tolkien. In its broadest sense however, fantasy comprises works by many writers, artists, filmmakers, and musicians, from ancient myths and legends to many recent works embraced by a wide audience today. Fantasy is a vibrant area of academic study in a number of disciplines (English, cultural studies, comparative literature, history, medieval studies). Work in this area ranges widely, from the structuralist theory of Tzvetan Todorov, which emphasizes the fantastic as a liminal space, to work on the connections (political, historical, literary) between medievalism and popular culture Source: Wiki

tag.name: comedy
tag.description: Anime whose central struggle causes hilarious results. These stories are built upon funny characters, situations and events. A comedy anime is laced with humour and sets out to provoke laughter from the audience. Japanese humour can be a bit strange to westerners, so if you`re new to this type of humour, just bear with it; it`ll most likely grow on you if you`re a fan of other kinds of comedy.

tag.name: henshin
tag.description: Japanese for "transformation" (metamorphosis or disguise). A "henshin anime" is any anime, where the characters or their costumes transform, such as Sailor Moon. The henshin switches on the character`s special powers, and is frequently accompanied by a costume change. Often the change of clothing is the only outward indicator that the character has changed and yet nobody seems to notice the hero`s true self. Most henshin heroes have a special item which they use to change into their heroic form. These items are usually activated by a command phrase (which is often in Engrish, for some reason), triggering a transformation sequence.

tag.name: ecchi
tag.description: Fan service is found in many anime, in many forms. When the service has a distinctly sexual slant to it, and it appears to be a major focus of the show, then it`s safe to assume you`re watching ecchi. The word "ecchi" is used by English-speaking anime fans to refer to refer to soft-core pornographic or sexually suggestive anime and manga. This is a western invention; in Japanese, it is a catch-all term for all things anyhow sexual in nature, not being limited to porn, but also not really considered a "milder" term, as it may also refer to sexual intercourse itself. The term "ecchi" in Japanese comes from the pronunciation of the letter "H" in English, which is rendered into Japanese syllabary as エッチ, which in turn is transliterated in the English alphabet as "ecchi" or "etchi". It is not, as many believe, short for "hentai" -- that, too, seems to be a western invention. It is, however, nearly as misunderstood and misapplied a term as "hentai". The line between ecchi and hentai, from the western perspective over these terms, can be hard to draw at times; one good rule of thumb is: if it was aired on Japanese public TV at all, it probably wasn`t hentai. Ecchi usually features all the specifics to human anatomy that can only be found in anime, and generally avoids full nudity, instead abusing of panty shots. Hentai, on the other hand, will usually show full frontal nudity in some explicit form, including genitalia, and full, intimate sex scenes. At its mildest, ecchi is composed of double entendres, big misunderstandings, and sexual farce; at its most explicit, it is still in the realm of softcore pornography, with full breast shots, full back nudity and similar content, but no display of genitalia. Another good way to distinguish the two is looking for animated sex scenes; if one is found, you have generally left the genre entirely, though a few borderline exceptions apply here. For AniDB`s purposes, the distinction between explicit ecchi and actual hentai is simple: if it was sold with a 18+ restriction in its country of origin, it is hentai; if it was sold without it, it is ecchi. Source: TV Tropes

tag.name: tragedy
tag.description: Tragedy is a form of drama characterized by seriousness and dignity, usually involving a conflict between a character and some higher power, such as the law, the gods, fate, or society.

tag.name: breasts
tag.description: The female bust size matters! Or does it? The three subcategories spell out the sizes that relate to fetishes, be they gigantic, large or small. Normal sized breasts are not a fetish, it seems. The tag is not only used for ecchi anime, but also for hentai shows as well.

tag.name: unsorted
tag.description: a bunch of tags that still need to be either deleted or moved into proper places.

tag.name: rotten world
tag.description: A rotten world is a setting or situation where the jaded notion that "anything that can go wrong will go horribly wrong" almost always applies. Oppression, perpetual warfare, lawlessness, despair or other forms of mental instability, and other highly undesirable factors tend to be rampant.

tag.name: funny expressions
tag.description: The facial expressions of the characters may change so quickly or unexpectedly distort that hilarity will ensue.

tag.name: male protagonist
tag.description: This anime has a male protagonist.

tag.name: emotions awaken superpowers
tag.description: During an extreme emotional state — rage, love, hate, angst, sadness, compassion — something inside the character will "click" that will increase greatly his/her power or a new superpower awakes, that surpasses anything achieved by him/her until then.

tag.name: everybody dies
tag.description: Not necessarily everyone, but a good portion of the characters kick the bucket.

tag.name: human experimentation
tag.description: Genetic, biological, chemical or psychological experimentation on human beings are portrayed or their aftermath is shown.

tag.name: facial distortion
tag.description: The characters face are exaggerated into a misshape, deformed, and almost warped. Used as comedy element to express extreme mood swings. Differing from "http://anidb.net/t2652 [Super Deformed]", here only the face changes to an extreme degree, not the whole body of the protagonist.

tag.name: gore
tag.description: A Splatter film or Gore film is a sub-genre of horror film that deliberately focuses on graphic portrayals of gore and graphic violence. These films, through the use of special effects and excessive blood and guts, tend to display an overt interest in the vulnerability of the human body and the theatricality of its mutilation. Due to their willingness to portray images society might consider shocking, splatter films share some ideological grounds with the transgressive art movement. The term "splatter cinema" was coined by George A. Romero to describe his film Dawn of the Dead, though Dawn of the Dead is generally considered by critics to have higher aspirations, such as social commentary, than to be simply exploitative for its own sake. [Source: wiki]

tag.name: OP and ED sung by characters
tag.description: OP and/or ED in this anime is sung by the characters and animation shows them singing.

tag.name: rebellion
tag.description:
Rebellion, uprising, or insurrection is a refusal of obedience or order. It may, therefore, be seen as encompassing a range of behaviors aimed at destroying or taking over the position of an established authority such as a government, governor, president, political leader, financial institution, or person in charge. On the one hand the forms of behaviour can include non-violent methods such as the (overlapping but not quite identical) phenomena of civil disobedience, civil resistance and nonviolent resistance. On the other hand it may encompass violent campaigns. Those who participate in rebellions, especially if they are armed rebellions, are known as "rebels".
Source: Wiki

tag.name: ensemble cast
tag.description:
A show with an ensemble cast focuses on a larger group of main characters in a single plot narrative; anime containing several segmented plot narratives (such as episodic or arc-based plots) are excluded. As such, it doesn`t really have a "main" or "lead" character; instead, every member of the central main character group plays an important part in the show`s grander scheme; no single character is more important or prominent than the others (equality of importance). Further, subplots (if any) lead by each character in the ensemble have equal weighting in importance (or lack of weight).
* In a show where no single main character is more important or prominent than the others, 4+ main characters is almost always an ensemble cast. * A show with 3 main characters of equal importance is likely also an ensemble cast; equality of importance must be considered carefully. * A show with 2 main characters of equal importance is generally not an ensemble cast situation; however, on an exception basis where neither main character is considered an antagonist, a 2-main-character anime may be considered an ensemble (e.g. http://anidb.net/a11829 [Kimi no Na wa.]).
Pictured: http://anidb.net/a9043 [K (anime)]

tag.name: murder
tag.description: To murder means to bring about someone else`s death, by a voluntary act. Whether it comes from the killer`s own hand or by exposing the victim to life-threatening circumstances, the result is foreseeable and sought by the perpetrator. Someone who murders as their profession/job is an http://anidb.net/t2399 [assassin or hitman].

tag.name: main character dies
tag.description: At least one of the main characters in the anime dies.

tag.name: lost technology
tag.description: Any advanced technology or science-related knowledge that was lost for some reason fits the description. This could be technology from a time before a post-apocalyptic cataclysm, knowledge gained a long time ago but forgotten, or the relics of an old alien civilization only recently discovered.

tag.name: imperialism
tag.description: Imperialism is a type of advocacy of empire. Its name originated from the Latin word "imperium", which means to rule over large territories. Imperialism is "a policy of extending a country`s power and influence through colonization, use of military force, or other means". Source: Wiki

tag.name: massacre
tag.description: Mass murder.

tag.name: ass-kicking girls
tag.description: The female characters in the anime are very proficient in some form of martial arts, swordplay, or gunfights. They may also have super powers.

tag.name: heroic sacrifice
tag.description: "In order to save the many, the few will need to sacrifice their lives..." or so this character may think. In a seemingly hopeless situation, against impossible odds, the character does not choose the path of the coward and run, he or she chooses to bravely face the enemy, fully aware that this will mean death.

tag.name: TO BE MOVED TO CHARACTER
tag.description: Tags under this parent tag are going to be moved to character tags and removed from the anime they`re currently assigned to. They will be blocked from the anime system once that move is complete. Please help with that job if you know what characters they should be assigned to.

tag.name: technical aspects
tag.description: It may sometimes be useful to know about technical aspects of a show, such as information about its broadcasting or censorship. Such information can be found here.

tag.name: tropes
tag.description: A trope is a commonly recurring literary and rhetorical devices, motifs or clichés in creative works. This use is a broader redefining of a literary trope, the use of figurative language, via word, phrase, or even an image, for artistic effect, such as using a figure of speech. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: death
tag.description: Death is the state of no longer being alive or the process of ceasing to be alive.

tag.name: torture
tag.description: Torture involves the deliberate act of inflicting pain, to either fulfill a desire of the torturer, or apply coercion to compel action from the victim. Torture, by definition, is a knowing and intentional act; deeds which unknowingly or negligently inflict pain without a specific intent to do so are not typically considered torture. This is distinct from http://anidb.net/t2905 [erotic torture], which is generally for the purpose of using (almost) any form of physical or excessive psychological abuse to inflict physical and/or mental pain, with the goal of inducing sexual pleasure.

tag.name: speculative fiction
tag.description: Speculative fiction is an umbrella genre encompassing fiction with certain elements that do not exist in the real world, often in the context of supernatural, futuristic or other imaginative themes. This includes, but is not limited to, science fiction, fantasy, superhero fiction, horror, utopian and dystopian fiction, fairytale fantasy, supernatural fiction, as well as combinations thereof. Source: Wikipedia

character.name: Night Raid
character.description: Night Raid is one of the covert divisions of the Revolutionary Army. Its main function is to handle intelligence and assassinations within the capital of the Empire. In addition, the members of Night Raid are charged with the retrieval of any Teigu discovered in order to boost the combat effectiveness of the Rebel Army. Source: akamegakill.wikia.com

episode.title: 帝具使いを斬る
Kill the Imperial Arm Users
Benutzer von Kaiserwaffen durchschneiden
Mort à l`adepte d`arme impériale
Teigu Tsukai o Kiru
episode.summary: The target this time is the capital’s rumored phantom serial killer known only as “Zank the Executioner.” Just like the Night Raid, he is an Imperial Arms user as well. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 蟠を斬る
Kill Your Cares
Die Befangenheit durchschneiden
Mort au ressentiment
Wadakama o Kiru
episode.summary: The Night Raid’s hideout is invaded by intruders! The assassin clan was able to drive out the enemy without a problem. Tatsumi experiences the true intensity of the Night Raid for the first time and he is thrilled. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 権力を斬る
Kill the Authority
Die Autorität durchschneiden
Mort au pouvoir
Kenryoku o Kiru
episode.summary: Tatsumi is taken by the Night Raid. They realized his potential as an assassin and asks him to join, but Tatsumi is conflicted. Though after learning more about each of Night Raid’s team members, he learns of their objectives to defeat evil and corruption and eventually decides to join. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 闇を斬る
Kill the Darkness
Die Dunkelheit durchschneiden
Mort aux ténèbres
Yami o Kiru
episode.summary: Tatsumi leaves his village in pursuit of wealth and success in the Imperial Capital. He attempts to join the army, however it isn’t as easy as it seems. When all of the sudden, a large breasted woman shows up at the local bar and offers to help him get recruited. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アカ斬る! 劇場: 第壱斬 タツミとレオーネ
AkaKILL! Theater: 1st Elimination - Tatsumi and Leone
Aka Kill! Gekijou: Dai Ichi Ki - Tatsumi to Leone
アカ斬る! 劇場: 第弐斬 1分間クッキング
AkaKILL! Theater: 2nd Elimination - One-Minute Cooking
Aka Kill! Gekijou: Dai Ni Ki - Ippunkan Cooking
三匹を斬る -後編-
Kill the Three -Part Two-
Drei Kleintiere durchschneiden - Teil 2
Mort aux bourreausquetaires (2e partie)
Sanbiki o Kiru -Kouhen-
episode.summary: Tatsumi and Bulat stand before the Three. Among them is Bulat’s former leader, Liver. The battle quickly turns into a one-on-one combat between Bulat versus Liver and Tatsumi versus Nyau. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 三匹を斬る -前編-
Kill the Three -Part One-
Drei Kleintiere durchschneiden - Teil 1
Mort aux bourreausquetaires (1re partie)
Sanbiki o Kiru -Zenpen-
episode.summary: General Esdeath arrives at the capital and is brought to the Emperor to discuss annihilating Night Raid. The Emperor wants to reward her for her services but her request is somewhat surprising. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 絶対正義を斬る
Kill the Absolute Justice
Die absolute Gerechtigkeit durchschneiden
Mort à la justice absolue
Zettai Seigi o Kiru
episode.summary: Night Raid is tasked with the eradication of a drug trafficking organization within the Imperial City. Tatsumi and Leone head towards the red light district. The two learn of the horrific details of the organization and their rage is apparent. Meanwhile, Sheele and Mine go after the Tybil, former leader of the organization when they suddenly feel an alarming presence. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 夢物語を斬る
Kill the Dream
Traumgeschichten durchschneiden
Mort aux chimères
Yumemonogatari o Kiru
episode.summary: Sheele, who has no particular role in the hideout is assigned as Tatsumi’s trainer. She explains how and why she chose assassinating as her career. Tatsumi, who still doesn’t have an Imperial Arm of his own, tests out the Imperial Arm taken from Zank. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アカ斬る! 劇場: 第参斬 温泉
AkaKILL! Theater: 3rd Elimination - Hot Spring

AkaKILL! Theater: 6th Elimination - Esdeath`s Fun Torture Classroom
Aka Kill! Gekijou: Dai Roku Ki - Esdeath no Tanoshii Goumon Kyoushitsu
新入りを斬る
Kill the Newcomers
Die Neuen durchschneiden
Mort aux nouveaux
Shin`iri o Kiru
episode.summary: After dealing with Dr. Stylish’s attack Night Raid leaves their base and hides in the mountains. After welcoming the newly joined member, Night Raid experienced a brief moment of peace, even amid training. Mine, who has been teased relentlessly Chelsea, the newcomer, tells Tatsumi and Lubbok that she wants revenge. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: マッドサイエンティストを斬る
Kill the Mad Scientist
Den Mad Scientist durchschneiden
Mort au savant fou
Mad Scientist o Kiru
episode.summary: Dr. Stylish discovered Night Raid’s hideout as he followed Tatsumi. A battle quickly commenced between Night Raid and Dr. Stylish’s fortified army who struck with a surprise attack. Tatsumi and Mine are enraged as they see Kakusan equipped with Sheele’s Imperial Arms Extase. A fierce battle continues within the hideout when suddenly something came down from the Sky... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 誘惑を斬る
Kill the Temptation
Die Verführung durchschneiden
Mort à la tentation
Yuuwaku o Kiru
episode.summary: Esdeath has taken Tatsumi after winning the combat tournament. And the reason being... love at first sight?! That being said Tatsumi has not only been forced to become Esdeath’s lover but also an auxiliary member of the Jaegers. Tatsumi and Esdeath observe as the Jaegers raid the bandits’ hideout; he witnesses how powerful the Jaegers truly are. All the while Tatsumi tries to find an opportunity to escape and return to the Night Raid’s hideout... Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 戦闘狂を斬る
Kill the Battle Fanatic
Den Kampfeswahn durchschneiden
Mort aux fous de combat
Sentoukyou o Kiru
episode.summary: Tatsumi inherits Bulat’s Imperial Arms Incrusio after defeating the Three and vows to become even stronger. Mine’s attitude towards Tatsumi seems to show a change after seeing his dedication during training... Meanwhile, General Esdeath receives news of the Three being defeated and in order to reinforce the army’s strength she organizes a special police force of Imperial Arms users known only as the Jeagars. Source: crunchyroll

教団を斬る
Kill the Religious Organization
Eine Religionsgemeinschaft durchschneiden
Mort à l`ordre religieux
Kyoudan o Kiru
episode.summary: A widely accepted religious organization among the civilians known as the Path of Peace is quickly gaining more followers. It is rumored that they will cause an armed uprising in an attempt to fight against the corrupt government. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 巨大危険種を斬る
Kill the Giant Danger Beast
Das Ministermonster durchschneiden
Mort aux créatures géantes
Kyodai Kikenshu o Kiru
episode.summary: Tatsumi and Esdeath meet again by chance while exterminating Danger Beasts. Esdeath is pleasantly surprised at the unexpected reunion while Tatsumi is overwhelmed. Even while fully immersed in the joy of their reunion, Esdeath notices that a man’s been watching them from the shadows. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 邪魔者を斬る
Kill the Nuisances
Hindernisse durchschneiden
Mort aux gêneurs
Jamamono o Kiru
episode.summary: A new species of Danger Beasts have emerged and has been terrorizing the vicinity of the capital. Minister Onest has ordered Esdeath to seize and defeat them. Esdeath leads the Jaegers to go to deal with them. But something suspicious in the shadow is keeping an eye on their actions. Meanwhile, after Night Raid settles into their new hideout, they’re also on the move to deal with the new Danger Beasts. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 人形を斬る
Kill the Puppets
Puppen durchschneiden
Mort aux pantins
Ningyou o Kiru
episode.summary: In order to combat the Jaegars, Night Raid is separated into two groups. Tatsumi and Akame are to deal with Bols, Kurome, and her puppets. The battle proves to be difficult as Kurome’s Imperial Arms “Yatsufusa” has the ability to freely control the dead. Source: crunchyroll

修羅を斬る
Kill the Carnage
Shura durchschneiden
Mort à Shura
Shura o Kiru
episode.summary: Kyoroch is freed because of Night Raid, which strengthens the Revolutionary Army`s power. In this dire situation, Commander-in-chief Budoh and the minister`s son, Shura, join the fight against Night Raid. Meanwhile, Night Raid infiltrates the capital yet again. Tatsumi and Lubbock go after Minister Onest in the palace by sneaking in with the help of one of the Revolutionary Army`s spies. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 因縁を斬る
Kill the Fate
Die Ursache durchschneiden
Mort à la fatalité
Innen o Kiru
episode.summary: Night Raid continues to work on their plan to assassinate Borick in Kyoroch. Tatsumi and Mine wander around the city, but then end up running into Seryu, who is responsible for Sheele`s death. Mine decides to end things once and for all with her, while Tatsumi fights Suzuka from the Four Demons. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 鬼を斬る
Kill the Demon
Dämonen durchschneiden
Mort aux démons
Oni o Kiru
episode.summary: Borick is scheming to take over a religious faction, and Night Raid heads to Kyoroch, where that religion has its headquarters. The Jaegars also head to Kyoroch to act as bodyguards for Borick. Wave is worried about Kurome, who still hasn`t healed from her wounds. Night Raid safely infiltrates Kyoroch, however they must now face Borick`s own appointed guards, the Four Koukenji Rakshasa Demons. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 呪縛を斬る
Kill the Curse
Den Bann durchschneiden
Mort au sortilège
Jubaku o Kiru
episode.summary: After being cornered by Akame and Leone, Bols sets off an explosion and flees. While he is trying to get back to his comrades, he runs into a hurt girl who is crying. Meanwhile, Kurome`s medicine starts wearing off and she starts remembering her days with Akame as well as their sad goodbye, while stumbling through the mountain. While leaning against a tree eating snacks, someone approaches her... Source: crunchyroll

AkaKILL! Theater: 17th Elimination - Ghost House

アカメが斬る!
Akame ga Kill!
Akame ga Kill
Akame ga Kill!
Akame ga Kiru!
episode.summary: The empire’s army has been defeated and all that remains is the empire’s strongest, General Esdeath. Akame and her sword stand in Esdeath’s way as she desires to continue breeding war. The two face one another. The final battle begins. What will the result bring forth? A new kingdom where the citizens can live in peace or will there be more bloodshed…? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 皇帝を斬る
Kill the Emperor
Den Kaiser durchschneiden
Mort à l`empereur
Koutei o Kiru
episode.summary: The Revolution finally reaches its final phase; Night Raid is en route to assassinate Minister Onest, the root of the problem. All goes according to Najenda’s plan as the Revolutionary Army successfully invades the city. Night Raid arrives at the Palace where the Emperor and Minister are located. Unlike the panicked Emperor, the Minister is composed and confident as they prepare to unleash their trump card. As the palace trembles, something appears from below...! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 妹を斬る
Kill the Little Sister
Die Schwester durchschneiden
Mort à la cadette
Imouto o Kiru
episode.summary: Following Tatsumi’s capture, Night Raid successfully defeated Commander-in-Chief Budou but at the cost of Main and Susanoo’s lives. The Revolutionary Army surrounds the capital as the civilians start to riot. Wave is confounded by what he sees as Ran calmly observes how everything unfolds. Meanwhile, Kurome senses that the end of her life is drawing near and seeks to settle things with her older sister once and for all. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 絶望を斬る
Kill the Despair
Die Verzweiflung durchschneiden
Mort au désespoir
Zetsubou o Kiru
episode.summary: In order to instill fear into the hearts of those among the Rebel Army, the capital has spread the word that Tatsumi will be executed publicly. Night Raid receives notice of this and intends to rescue him. Source: crunchyroll
